head.title: Stolen Treasures, and a Lost Heritage

identified-content.location: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

hedline.hl1: Stolen Treasures, and a Lost Heritage

abstract.p: Marina Papa Sokal letter on Aug 29 article on expansion of Metropolitan Museum's Asian art collection urges efforts to curb pillaging of archaeological sites; drawing

block.p: Re ''Changing of the Guard for a Vast Empire; After Whirlwind Expansion, the Met's New Chairman of Asian Art Takes His Time'' (Arts pages, Aug. 29):
Re ''Changing of the Guard for a Vast Empire; After Whirlwind Expansion, the Met's New Chairman of Asian Art Takes His Time'' (Arts pages, Aug. 29):
The growing public interest in art from Asia, fostered by the Met and other museums, is certainly heartening.

But there is a downside: the pillaging of archaeological sites to feed the increasing demand from collectors and dealers, as exemplified by the recent case of a stolen 10th-century Chinese marble sculpture (news article, March 30) and by the large-scale looting of Cambodian temples (news article, April 1, 1999).

Museums must refuse to acquire pieces lacking a documented provenance, and governments must collaborate to carry out better international controls on the antiquities trade. If not, a large part of the world's cultural heritage will simply disappear.
MARINA PAPA SOKAL New York, Aug. 31, 2000
